instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - NO PP3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V/0.04A - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> Shorting
threads.message:
Got this board with small amount of liquid damage around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>, a quite similar case to [URL='https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a-wont-start-missing-<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.59917/#post-64478']@CRC2018 - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Wont start missing [/URL]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
Another area which had some liquid damage was <CAPACITOR>C3403</CAPACITOR>, which seems a bit corroded but still makes good contact.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V - 0.43Vdc
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V - 0 Ohm - Short

<CHIP>U7650</CHIP>
PIN4 - 0V
PIN12 - 0V
PIN13 - 0V
PIN21 - 0V
PIN22 - 3.3V
PIN29 - 0V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO5V</SIGNAL> - 4.89v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL> - 3.18v

<SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> - 0v - 0.46Vdc
<SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL> -3.17V - 0.48Vdc - <RESISTOR>R7828</RESISTOR> present,  /29 not present

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.40V - SMC seems ok?
<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.40V
<SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> - 3.12V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> - 3.408V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> - 1.19V
<RESISTOR>R7883</RESISTOR> is fine

<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> - 0V - 5 Ohm

Could this short be caused by a bad PMIC? Any suggestion what else I can check on it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - NO PP3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V/0.04A - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> Shorting
threads.message:
Short on RTC can be caused by PMIC, or PCH.
Find the culprit which causes short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> first; could be just PMIC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - NO PP3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V/0.04A - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> Shorting
threads.message: How would you advise to go with this short? Can I inject in there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - NO PP3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V/0.04A - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> Shorting
threads.message:
Should be safe to inject, no more than 4V.
Start with 1V and go high slowly, if needed.
Unfortunately, no idea about the ohm value of that short...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - NO PP3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V/0.04A - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> Shorting
threads.message:
Aaah had the same working board 2 hrs ago could have measured it. 
Thank you again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - NO PP3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 20V/0.04A - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> Shorting
threads.message: The short is in the actual board...
